questions.question: During the monetary policy tightening period from May 2022 to December 2024, the repo rate increased by 250 basis points. options.A: Transmission to fresh deposit rates was higher in PVBs, while transmission to fresh lending rates was higher in PSBs.
options.B: PSBs demonstrated higher transmission than PVBs in both fresh deposit rates and fresh lending rates.
options.C: PVBs showed stronger transmission than PSBs across both fresh deposit and fresh lending rates.
options.D: Transmission to fresh lending rates was higher in PVBs, while transmission to fresh deposit rates was higher in PSBs.
options.E: Both bank groups experienced identical transmission in fresh deposit rates, but PSBs had a lower transmission in fresh lending rates.

The Weighted Average Domestic Term Deposit Rate (WADTDR) on fresh deposits increased by 274 bps for PSBs compared to 214 bps for Private Sector Banks (PVBs). questions.question:
In a move to attract more capital inflows, the RBI revised the interest rate ceilings on FCNR(B) deposits in December 2024. Which of the following statements regarding this revision is/are correct?
1. The ceiling for deposits with a maturity of 1 year to less than 3 years has been increased to overnight ARR plus 400 bps.
2. The ceiling for deposits with a maturity of 3 to 5 years has been increased to overnight ARR plus 500 bps.
3. The relaxation in interest rate ceilings is available until March 31, 2025.
questions.explanation: All three statements are correct. Banks are permitted to raise fresh FCNR(B) deposits of 1 year to less than 3 years maturity at rates not exceeding overnight Alternative Reference Rate (ARR) plus 400 bps (up from 250 bps). For deposits of 3 to 5 years maturity, the ceiling has been increased to overnight ARR plus 500 bps (up from 350 bps). This relaxation is available till March 31, 2025. (Page 12, 21)
